Title.evidence: Incidence and Impact of Rib Fracture in Thoracotomy: A Retrospective Analysis

Trial_Design.evidence: This retrospective study was conducted at a single institution

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients over 18 years undergoing thoracotomy, excluding those with traumatic etiology or osteoporosis.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the incidence of rib fractures, associated risk factors, and their relationship with post-operative pain and complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Pain was assessed using the Visual Analogue Scale, and 30-day post-operative complications were recorded.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 367 patients were included

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patients with rib fractures experienced higher evoked pain at 48 hours post-surgery (p = 0.039) and a higher incidence of complications (32/179 vs 20/188; p = 0.047).

Harms.evidence: Patients with rib fractures experienced higher evoked pain at 48 hours post-surgery (p = 0.039) and a higher incidence of complications (32/179 vs 20/188; p = 0.047).
